heading: wall street: post-party blah?
subheading: after monday's big day when the dow set an all-time high, the stock market was expected to be a bit more mellow, especially since interest rates are expected to rise.
author: reuters
text: new york -- wall street was expected to open flat to lower on tuesday, a day after the dow set an all-time high, with high expectation the federal reserve will raise interest rates exactly as predicted. but no more and no less."we're on fed watch here and the markets have already celebrated," said peter cardillo, director of research at westfalia investments.until the afternoon decision, the markets were expected to mark time, analysts said."i would say some profit-taking and some milling about rather than a dramatic move," said larry wachtel, a market analyst at prudential securities inc. "that's it -- nothing ahead of the fed."the benchmark 30-year us treasury bond was down 3/32 with a yield of 5.98 percent. the standard & poors future index for september was down 2.4 at 1,363.the policy-setting body of the federal reserve, the federal open market committee, was expected to raise interest rates to slow the economy to head off inflation. the announcement was expected about 2:15 p.m. edt.the market expects a rise in the short-term interest rates of 25 basis points.the fed last raised short-term rates on 30 june, when it moved its fed funds target rate up 25 basis points to 5.0 percent from 4.75 percent. the fed funds rate is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans."what the street would like to see is what it expects," wachtel said. but if the fed moves rates as expected, the market is not likely to move, he said."what's left? if we get what we expect, it's an anti-climax," wachtel said.anything more aggressive could be bad for stocks, and anything less could briefly hurt the bond market, which has already built in the expected 25-basis point hike, wachtel said.cardillo said the worst-case scenario would be for the fed to merely tighten its bias, indicating it would be inclined to increase rates in the future. that action would keep taut reins on the market, focusing it on every piece of economic news for hints of the next action.the dow jones industrial average closed 199.15 points higher on monday at 11,299.76. the previous record close for the dow was 11,209.84, reached on 16 july.the nasdaq rose 71.24 points, or 2.69 percent, to 2,719.57. and the standard & poor's 500 stock index rose 23.61 points, or 1.77 percent, to 1,360.22.copyright
